metadata./Title: Healing by secondary intention over NeoDura applicated on a craniectomy defect: a case report and literature review

sections.Background:
Background NeoDura (Medprin Biotech Gmbh) is an absorbable dural repair patch consisting of degradable 
poly- l-lactic acid and porcine gelatin that provides a hermetic closure of the dura mater (Medprin Biotech. Neodura. 
Dural Repair Patch [Brochure]. 2016. https:// irp. cdn-  websi te. com/ 76256 3d2/ files/ uploa ded/a- NeoDu ra- Brosc hüre. 
pdf. Accessed 24 Sep 2022.). It can be used after resection of a meningioma. If overlying bone and skin structures 
are absent, an additional flap reconstruction is usually considered, resulting in extensive surgery. However, this study 
is the first to describe a case of healing by secondary intention over NeoDura as the most superficial layer.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 48-year-old Caucasian woman had been treated with surgery and whole brain radiotherapy 
for medulloblastoma in 1976. As radiotherapy-related consequences she developed blindness and multiple secondary tumors (meningioma, basal cell carcinoma). After resection of a large parasagittal meningioma, wound infection and healing problems occurred. The skull flap (10 cm in diameter) had to be removed, and two latissimus dorsi 
reconstructions failed. As the dura closure using NeoDura appeared watertight, it was decided to attempt healing 
by secondary intention using vacuum assisted closure, and later, with local wound dressings. This resulted in a complete skin closure after almost 1 year. No local or neurological complications occurred. The tissue was sufficiently 
resistant to avoid the “syndrome of the trephined,” a well-known complication in patients without bony reconstruction 
after craniectomy.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion This is the first description of healing by secondary intention over a craniectomy wound where the nor mal dura was also removed and replaced by NeoDura. This treatment could be an alternative for extensive reconstructions in patients who are not fit to undergo reconstructive surgery or after failure of reconstruction.
Keywords  NeoDura, healing by secondary intention, craniectomy, dural repair patch
Background
Resection of intracranial tumoral processes may force the 
neurosurgeon to perform a craniectomy and breach the 
meninges. A tight seal is then required to prevent leakage 
of cerebrospinal fluid and the associated infections, head aches, and vision changes [12].
If primary closure of the dura mater is not possible, the 
use of grafts is possible. Since the late nineteenth cen tury, several types of material have been investigated, 
namely autografts, allografts, xenografts, and synthetic 
grafts, to establish the ideal dural replacement. Various †Axelle Stockmans, Quentin Dumont and Jos Velleman are joint first authors.

However, if overlying bone is damaged as well, an addi tional flap reconstruction can be considered. This often

results in very extensive surgery.
This study presents a patient treated with a dural sub stitute after resection of a large parasagittal meningioma. 
The uniqueness of this case lies in the healing by second ary intention over NeoDura as the most superficial layer 
after failure of the overlying flap reconstruction and the 
removal of the autologous bone owing to infection.
sections.Methods:
Methods
Case report
All information was retrieved from the University Hospi tals Leuven electronic medical file database. The patient 
provided informed consent.
Literature review
A PubMed literature search was executed from October 
2021 to 30 January 2023. The search terms were “second ary healing, ” “scalp bone defect, ” “NeoDura, ” and “tre phined. ” A total of 17 results were found.
Results
Case presentation
A 48-year-old Caucasian woman had been treated with 
resection and whole brain radiotherapy for cerebellar 
medulloblastomas at the age of 3 years. This resulted in 
blindness, pituitary insufficiency, atrophy of the skin with 
alopecia, and the development of an occipital basal cell 
carcinoma that was resected. Moreover, she developed 
post-radiotherapy meningiomas. Resection of meningi omas was performed 10  years ago. Now, the neurosur gery department executed the resection of a recurrent 
rapidly growing frontal parasagittal meningioma. Simp son grade I resection was achieved. NeoDura was applied 
for closure of the dura, and the skull was closed through 
replacement of the native skull fragments, which were 
affixed with small titanium plates, and a primary closure 
of the skin was possible. Then, 3 months later, the patient 
presented at the emergency department with a crust 
on the scar of the scalp and redness of the surrounding 
skin. Resection of the crust caused evacuation of sero purulent liquid. An underlying infection was diagnosed 
and a debridement was necessary. The skull fragments, 
with a total diameter of 10 cm, were infected as well as 
the overlying fragile skin. The skull fragments and over lying skin were resected. During the operation, incor poration of the Neodura in the surrounding native dura was observed, and a watertight closure of the dura was 
seen. As there was no evidence for subdural infection, 
the dura was left intact, and soft tissue coverage of the 
10 cm diameter defect was obtained by a free latissimus 
dorsi flap [5, 8]. Then, 2 days later, the flap was revised for 
arterial insufficiency and ultimately failed after 1  week. 
The flap was removed and coverage of the defect was per formed by a contralateral free latissimus dorsi flap. How ever, 4 days later, this flap also failed because of arterial 
insufficiency. The avital flap was removed and vacuum 
assisted closure (VAC) was started. At 1.5 months later 
the patient left the hospital with VAC therapy. The VACdressing was changed every 3–4  days during outpatient 
consultations. After 3 months, a superficial wound infec tion occurred. Stagnation of the granulation process, bad 
odor of the wound, and a small amount of pus at the edge 
of the wound were observed. Wound culture was positive 
for Staphylococcus aureus. Clindamycin was started and 
VAC-therapy was replaced with daily wound care con sisting of intensive cleaning of the wound and application 
of Flaminal Forte. After 10  days, the signs of infection 
disappeared. Clindamycin was stopped and daily wound 
care was continued unchanged. Gradual closure of the 
skin was observed (Fig.  1). At 1 year later, the skin was 
completely closed and well healed (Fig.  1). The patient 
did not experience any new neurological symptoms. 
No leakage of cerebrospinal fluid from the wound was 
observed during follow-up. There was no need for a cer ebrospinal fluid diversion procedure or lumbar puncture. 
Since the patient did not experience any symptoms sug gestive of the syndrome of the trephined, no reconstruc tion of the bone was performed, in agreement with the 
patient. The 1 year postoperative computed tomography 
(CT) scan showed a normal aspect of the ventricles, no 
midline shift, no signs of changed intracranial pressure, 
and no external hydrocephalus (Fig. 2).
Literature review
Healing by secondary intention
Healing by secondary intention consists of a combination 
of migration of fibroblasts and keratinocytes, and wound 
contraction. The disadvantages of healing by secondary 
intention are alopecia, large scar formation, contour mis match, and a longer healing time [2, 8].
Fibroblasts are critical in supporting normal wound 
healing by creating new extracellular matrix in a process 
called granulation [2]. The formation of a new extracellu lar matrix makes the filling of a wound possible.
To complete the process of wound healing, the for mation of a new epithelial surface is needed. The epi dermis is composed of several layers of keratinocytes. 
Keratinocytes are responsible for the process of reepi thelialization and participate in host defense during

wound healing [10]. When healing through secondary 
intention, keratinocytes migrate and proliferate from 
the wound edges, the hair follicles, sebaceous glands, 
and sweat glands over the denuded area. Multiple regu lators, such as cytokines, integrins, keratins, matrix 
metalloproteinases, and growth factors, modulate the 
migration of keratinocytes, and consequently, the pro cess of wound healing [3]. To form the top layers of the 
epidermis, keratinocytes migrate upward and undergo 
differentiation.
Syndrome of the trephined
The syndrome of the trephined is a rare phenomenon 
that occurs after decompressive craniectomy in which the skull is not replaced. The incidence of the syndrome 
of the trephined has been reported between 7 and 26%, 
however, it has been poorly described and underdi agnosed as a result. The syndrome is characterized by 
severe headaches, pain, discomfort, vertigo, apprehen sion, tinnitus, insomnia, seizures, memory disturbance, 
behavioral disturbance, mood swings, and mental 
depression [7]. Not only the syndrome of the trephined, 
but also other syndromes, such as the “syndrome of the 
sinking scalp flap” and “motor trephined syndrome” to 
describe focal neurological deficits or motor deficits, are 
known in this type of patient [7]. The mechanism has not 
been fully elucidated. A few theories have been proposed, 
such as the effect of the atmospheric air directly onto the

brain, changes in the cerebral blood flow and metabo lism, but also the flow and pressure of cerebrospinal 
fluid (CSF) seem to play an important role in the clini cal presentation [7]; this can be explained by the external 
barometric pressure exceeding the intracranial pressure, 
causing a decreased blood flow. Moreover, the sugges tion has been made that impaired CSF circulation after 
injury could cause a transgression of CSF and edema of the parenchyma underlying the skull defect [4]. It still is 
not understood why some patients develop symptoms 
and others do not [7]. Treatment consists of replacing the 
skull defect using some cranioplasty technique (e.g., tita nium, polyetheretherketone) [3].
What is NeoDura?
NeoDura is an absorbable dural repair patch made of syn thetic material (poly-l-lactic acid) and porcine gelatin [9, 
11]. Gelatin is a natural polymer derived from nonsolu ble collagen. Gelatin is biocompatible with human tissue, 
flexible, stable, and can be modified to act as a scaffold 
base [ 11]. It does not trigger any immune response in the 
human body. The amino acids present in collagen act as 
a hemostatic agent to initiate wound healing and absorb 
exudates. The migration and adhesion of migrating cells, 
such as fibroblasts, is thereby promoted [1].
Screening for similar articles
No articles were identified describing the process of sec ondary healing over NeoDura applicated on a craniec tomy wound. Consequently, this paper is to the best of 
our knowledge the first to publish this process. One arti cle describes the process of secondary closure of skin 
over a scalp defect in a case of aplasia cutis congenital 
[6]. However, this newborn had a normal dura. After 
debridement and moist wound care, the defect closed 
over a period of 20 weeks. The bone defect also decreased 
over months to years.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
The NeoDura provided a strong and reliable watertight 
seal over which the process of tissue granulation and 
secondary skin closure was possible. The entire process 
took 1  year and even overcame an episode of infection. 
The patient never experienced any symptoms of the syn drome of the trephined. Healing by secondary intention 
was not the first choice. However, owing to failed flap 
reconstructions and infection, it was the only option 
left. Once skin started to migrate inward, closure was 
obtained rapidly. Therefore, a skin graft was not per formed. Alopecia is still present.
To the best of our knowledge, this is the first descrip tion of secondary healing over NeoDura applicated on a 
craniectomy wound.
Limitations of the study
This study reports only one patient in who second ary healing was successful, and who did not experience 
symptoms suggestive of the syndrome of the trephined. 
It is unknown if this can be generalized. Healing by sec ondary intention over a duraplasty should be reserved for 
exceptional cases.

Conclusion
This is the first case report that illustrates that healing 
through secondary intention over NeoDura applicated 
on a craniectomy wound is possible in patients who are 
not candidates for complex reconstructions. The Neo Dura provided a watertight seal over which the granula tion process and skin closure was possible. The wound 
closed after a year guided by wound care. The patient did 
not experience any symptoms suggestive of the syndrome 
of the trephined. It is unknown if this can be generalized.
